title: How Carmel plans to fight climate change
text:
How Carmel plans to fight climate change Chris Sikich , chris.sikich@indystar.com Published 7:04 a.m. ET Feb. 21, 2017 | Updated 22 minutes ago Buy Photo The agreement calls for Carmel to buy the 1.68-acre city block at the southwest corner of Main Street and the Monon in the Arts & Design District from Chuck Lazzara and transfer it back to him by Jan. 1, 2017. (Photo: Charlie Nye/IndyStar 2010 file photo) Buy Photo CONNECT 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Carmel is taking on climate change. 
The City Council unanimously approved a resolution Monday to measure citywide emissions and work toward reducing them. 
Two groups , the Carmel Green Initiative and Earth Charter Indiana , helped draft the resolution. 
Leslie Webb, president of the Carmel Green Initiative, said this was a youth-led process to help protect the future of the city. She said this was the first such resolution an Indiana city has passed and advocates hope to convince more communities to sign on. She said Indianapolis is considering a similar resolution. 
Six local students involved with the two groups   resolution. They pointed out 97 percent of climate scientists agree human activity is worsening climate change, a fact that also is noted on NASA's web page . 
Miranda Frausto, 17, a senior at Carmel High School, said now is the time to act. She realizes Carmel is only one community, but hopes others follow suit. 
"We are kind of ignoring everything that is going on with climate change," she said, "and we as the youth who are going to be affected by this when we are older need to take action for our futures." 
Jodh Pullela, 14, a freshman at Carmel High School, noted climate scientists believe problems such as flooding, migrations, energy and food shortages will worsen if climate change is left unchecked. 
"I don't want to experience any of that in my lifetime," he said. 
Mayor Jim Brainard has long been an advocate of fighting climate change. In 2013, Brainard was named to a task force on climate change created by President Barack Obama. In December 2015, he took a trip on behalf of the U.S. Department of State to India and Germany to discuss ways to build sustainable cities. 
Brainard said the resolution will help the city continue along its current policies. He has a four-page list of ways the city strives for energy efficiency, including everything from purchasing hybrid and bio-fuel vehicles, planting trees, to requiring developers to create storm water pollution prevention plans to, of course, keeping traffic moving by building roundabouts instead of traffic signals. 
More Carmel news: Carmel prepares for 96th Street construction Council approves ordinance targeting clerk treasurer 
The Council unanimously approved an ordinance to transfer responsibilities for the city's comprehensive annual financial report, plus $106,500 in related expenses, from Clerk-Treasurer Christine Pauley's office to Brainard's office. 
Council members have been unhappy with the slow progress of last year's report , which is of 2015 expenses. Pauley remains responsible for that report, but this ordinance would impact annual reviews from this year forward. 
Pauley hired longtime city consultant Curt Coonrod to do last year's deep-dive review of city finances. She was seeking a Certificate of Achievement for Excellence from the Government Finance Officers Association, an important designation in government circles that could lead to lower bond ratings. 
Coonrod and Pauley have not been seeing eye to eye on some of his accounting methods, though.
